text.text: A Guide to Herne Hill

Super close to Brixton, but feeling a whole lot more villagey and chilled, Herne Hill has some proper unusual little finds. From an old school lido to a secret cinema stashed underneath a restaurant, if you get bored here then you're just telling porkies.
Best for... food with a soundtrack

tip.text:
20 years and still going strong, anyone who lives in Herne Hill knows Cafe Provencal. It's an all day affair here - big breakfasts in the morning (including a cracking vegan one), seriously tasty playlists during the day, homemade sweet goodies from Jeni Cakes for the afternoon, and in the evening it turns real cosy for dinner.

On that front, their signature lamb burger with garlic chips is what you need in your life, along with a beer from the Canopy Beer Co microbrewery which is just round the corner. Their Great Sunday Busk is a local institution, with artists from across London pitching up to play.

text.text: 20+ years and still going strong, anyone who lives in Herne Hill knows Cafe Provencal. It's an all day affair here - big breakfasts in the morning (including a cracking vegan one), seriously tasty playlists during the day, homemade sweet goodies from Jeni Cakes for the afternoon, and in the evening it turns real cosy for dinner. Their Great Sunday Busk is a local institution, with artists from across London pitching up to play.
Best for... a splash and a snack

tip.text:
London lidos are typically all about British tradition, but the cafe at Brockwell goes full 21st century on its menu. Instead of simple scones, you've got turkey bone-broth ramen with pickled ginger and pumpkin noodles. Rather than just tea, you've got a whole range of Tiger Spring loose leaf to get you warmed up if the water outside has been cold enough.

Seriously, the level of cooking here feels like top restaurant quality disguised in a humble cafe. It's a great sun trap in the afternoon, and you can look out on the water at that healthy lot doing laps.

text.text:
London lidos may be all about tradition, but the cafe at Brockwell goes full 21st century on its menu. Instead of simple scones, you've got turkey bone-broth ramen with pickled ginger and pumpkin noodles. Rather than just tea, you've got a whole range of Tiger Spring Loose leaf to get you warmed up if the water outside has been cold enough to leave you with two lumps in your throat. 

Seriously, the level of cooking here feels like a standalone restaurant rather than a cafe. It's a great sun trap in the afternoon, and you can look out on the water at that healthy lot doing laps.
Best for... pizza you can rely on

tip.text:
500 Degrees is a snazzy spot serving up banging pizza. This ain't just any old 'za tho, this is proper authentic Neapolitan pizza - with bubbly, stretchy crusts and all. The folks running this joint source most of their ingredients direct from Italy, bringing in a regular stream of Italian punters and making these guys bona fide purveyors of pizza. Yee-haww.

Toppings are fresh and delicious: from crushed tomatoes, ham, mushrooms, olives and artichokes (Capricciosa) to courgette, cherry tomatoes and pecorino (Scapece). There's also a selection of yummy salad dishes and calzones. Whatever you pick, you can rest assured it's gonna be damn tasty.

text.text: 500 Degrees is a snazzy spot serving up banging pizza. This ain't just any old 'za tho, this is proper authentic Neapolitan pizza, with bubbly, stretchy crusts and all. One of three 500 Degrees joints in South, they source most of their ingredients direct from Italy, bringing in a regular stream of Italian punters and locals in the know for good, quick and inexpensive feeding.
Best for... the perfect pint

tip.text: Long gone are the days you'd only travel to Herne Hill for the lido or the annual dog show (we recommend both, obviously). This brewery-cum-bar is one of many new additions to the arches. Originally known for its on-site craft beer brewing, Canopy has since opened a small bar and added a few tables and stools for a low-key locals' watering hole. Drink in or pick up a Sunray Pale Ale to go. For the non beer lovers we suggest the Bermondsey-made gin.

text.text: Long gone are the days you'd only travel to Herne Hill for the lido or the annual dog show (we recommend both, obviously). This brewery-cum-bar is one of many new additions to the arches. Originally known for its onsite craft beer brewing, Canopy has since opened a small bar and added a few tables 'n stools for a low key, locals' watering hole. Drink in or pick up a Sunray Pale Ale to go. For the non beer lovers we suggest the Bermondsey-made gin.
Best for... a cosy boozer

tip.text: Posh pub with good grub, you could certainly do worse than the Florence. Cosy is the operative word here: there is both a fireplace and a garden to be had. The food menu is eclectic, boasting everything from popcorn chicken to noodle vegan-ara to Jagermeister-glazed short rib. Incidentally, it's damn good. Look out for their brunch menu in particular, the crab and poached eggs are a real highlight. The pub also brews three of their own ales on-site, making this a truly well-rounded drinking hole.

text.text: Posh pub with good grub, you could certainly do worse than the Florence. Cosy is the operative word here: there is both a fireplace and a garden to be had, whilst the food menu is eclectic and excellent. Look out for their brunch menu in particular - the crab and poached eggs are a real highlight. The pub brews three of their own ales on-site, and has live jazzy jams on a Saturday night making it a truly well-rounded drinking hole.
Best for... pumping yourself full of vitamins

tip.text:
It may look super contemporary inside with the all-white, minimalism feel, but The Parlour keeps things classic with a good selection of homemade cakes and sandwiches. Gluten-free options are on offer too. Best part though is the inside 'garden' with the fake grass – everyone needs a bit of winter escapism.

Their coffee is consistently bang on, and there's a good smoothie and juice selection for when you need to get some vitamins in you, stat. If your hangover is biblical, ask them to add a shot of spirulina to your mix - it works almost as well as IRN-BRU.

text.text: It may look super contemporary inside with the all-white, minimalism feel, but The Parlour keeps things classic with a good selection of homemade cakes and sandwiches. Gluten-free options are on offer too. Best part though is the inside 'garden' with the fake grass. If you're not into fake grass, there's no hope for you. Their coffee is consistently bang on, and there's a good smoothie and juice selection for when you need to get some vitamins in you, stat.
Best for... fish and chips

tip.text:
Guaranteed you won't have been to a chippy like Olley's. Yeah, the takeaway half looks pretty normal, but the restaurant is like some mental Swiss skiing chalet with reclaimed church pews thrown in for good measure.

The fish? Oh sweet lord, a real winner. Mondays and Tuesdays are dedicated gluten-free night (there are even 6+ gluten-free beers), and they do specials like battered salmon too. They've won tonnes of sustainable sourcing awards here, so you can destroy a fish supper without the added guilt of plundering the oceans and that.

text.text: Guaranteed you won't have been to a chippy like Olley's. Yeah, the takeaway half looks pretty normal, but the restaurant is like some mental Swiss skiing chalet with reclaimed church pews thrown in for good measure. The fish itself, including battered salmon and gluten-free options, is goddamn delicious. So much so that they've won tonnes of sustainable sourcing awards, so you can destroy a fish supper without the added guilt of plundering the oceans and that.
Best for... that healthy/unhealthy mix

tip.text: From the guys behind Brixton fave, Shrub & Shutter, First Aid Box is an all day cafe and cocktail bar healing South Londoners with fresh juices, coffee from Alchemy Coffee and a food menu featuring plenty of raw fish and quality meat from local butchers. Cocktails are inspired by "health, nutrition and doctors orders" so no excuses for not getting stuck in.

text.text: From the guys behind Brixton fave, Shrub & Shutter, First Aid Box is an all day cafe and cocktail bar healing South Londoners with fresh juices, coffee from Alchemy Coffee and a food menu featuring plenty of raw fish and quality meat from local butchers. It's the cocktails that really set this place apart though, with cocktails inspired by "health, nutrition and doctors orders". So no excuses for not getting stuck in.
Best for... table tennis and tepees

tip.text: Some things try to be all things to all men. And that's the case with this place: a one stop spot for everything fun related that isn't illegal and won't end in regret. On any day of the week find DJs, live bands, stand-up comedy, open mic, table tennis, tepees, garden frolicking... the list goes on. Actually it doesn't that's the list. But that's enough for you.

text.text: Some things try to be all things to all men. And that's the case with this place: a one stop spot for everything fun related that isn't illegal and won't end in regret. On any day of the week find DJs, live bands, stand-up comedy, open mic, table tennis, tepees, garden frolicking... the list goes on. Actually it doesn't, that's the list. But that's enough for you.
Best for... that special dine out

tip.text:
Herne Hill has us all jealous of its culinary centrepiece, Llewelyn’s - a charming neighbourhood restaurant run by an A-Team of heavy hitters from St John, Rochelle Canteen, and Jamie Oliver’s 15. The place is chic, airy, and comfortable, serving up modern European food prepared and presented to a crazy high standard in a casual atmosphere.

The menus change daily with a focus on whatever seasonal produce is killing it at the time, but you can expect innovative delights such as confit duck leg with bacon, prunes, and wild garlic, or a rabbit niçoise with pickled onions, cherry tomatoes, and a poached egg. Also, be sure to try the puddings for a masterclass in decadent delicacy.

text.text:
This is Herne Hill's culinary centrepiece - a charming neighbourhood restaurant that's chic, airy, and comfortable, serving up modern European food prepared and presented to a crazy high standard in a casual atmosphere. 

The menus change daily with a focus on whatever seasonal produce is killing it at the time, but you can expect innovative delights such as confit duck leg with bacon, prunes, and wild garlic, or a rabbit niçoise with pickled onions, cherry tomatoes, and a poached egg. It's fine dining at a reasonable price.
Best for... railway arch frolics

tip.text:
In a sorta sexy ramshackle setting, down under the railway arches of Herne Hill, you’ll find one of South London's finest live music establishments. Yas indeed, because Off the Cuff may have started as a private members' club for posh folk with a penchant for wine and cheese, but its current incarnation is chilled and much more inclusive.

The room in the front is filled with vintage sofas for you to chat politics and recline on, complete with over-priced beer and retro furnishings. Whilst the back room is set up with a decent sound system, welcoming in an eclectic roster of bands and DJs on a relatively daily basis. There are also film screenings, poetry readings, and dances on offer, so you can get comfy, get tipsy and get educated on a Wednesday night.

text.text: Off the Cuff may have started as a private members' club for posh folk with a penchant for wine and cheese, but its current incarnation is chilled and clearly hipster friendly. The room in the front is filled with vintage sofas for you to chat politics and recline on, complete with over-priced beer and retro furnishings; the back has the sound system and the DJs. There are also film screenings, poetry readings, and dances on offer, so you can get comfy, get tipsy and get educated on a Wednesday night.
